awd_titl_txt: CIF: Small: Transcoding: A New Approach For Multi-hop Communications
awd_abstract_narration:
As one of the main driving forces behind modern ubiquitous communication and computing, new 5G wireless technologies aim for substantially broader coverage (10-100x number of connected devices) with special focus on supporting low-power Internet-of-Things (IoT) devices, which will further propel the ongoing revolution within the telecommunications and high-tech industries for the next decade. One key technique underpinning the latest development of 5G and beyond standards is the use of multi-hop wireless connections and advanced backhauling to enable flexible extension of range and coverage area. Nonetheless, the industry-standard multi-hop communication schemes are still based on concepts developed 40 years ago, which incur intolerably high complexity and long delay with respect to the high throughput (1-10Gbps) and low latency (1ms) requirements of 5G networks and beyond. There is thus an urgent need for new multi-hop communication paradigms that simultaneously optimize throughput, delay, and complexity.

This project proposes a new multi-hop communication paradigm called transcoding, a much needed revamp of the 40-year old industry standard called decode-and-forward. Specifically, transcoding takes a back-to-basics approach, which reexamines and analyzes the causes of the long-delay and high-complexity of the decode-&-forward policies. New strategies will then be designed accordingly, which will substantially improve the delay-tradeoff performance of multi-hop communications while significantly lowering the complexity. By breaking away from the decode-&-forward paradigm, the fundamentally new design philosophy of transcoding takes full advantage of the exciting recent development in single-hop wireless communications and in information theory. The results of this project will lead to new structured, low-complexity multi-hop "transcoders" that achieve high-throughput and low-latency necessary for the emerging 5G and IoT applications. The approaches and activities in this project include theoretical capacity analysis, new signal processing designs, network resource optimization, and testbed implementation and performance verification.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The commercial impact of multi-hop communication has been relatively minimal to date.  There are a number of emerging applications, however, that are driving new use cases. 5G and beyond wireless systems are expected to be deployed in much higher densities than previous networks.  These broadband wireless systems depend heavily on backhaul, which has historically been implemented using wireline techniques.  The sheer number of future base stations and access points necessitates replacing/upgrading existing wireline solutions with wireless ones that operate seamlessly and cost-effectively in multi-hop cellular deployments.  Furthermore, Internet of Things (IoT) deployments could lead to massive access problems that require new wireless solutions for multi-hop systems.

Additionally, the new wireless multi-hop backhaul systems must meet the continually tightening latency requirements that are critical to the various applications that will run on the next-generation cellular networks.  Most prior research in signal processing and information theory has focused on throughput-based multi-hop designs, and the proposed solutions generally exhibit exceedingly long delay that scales poorly in a multi-hop environment.

Our goal in this project analyzed the fundamental limits and designed practical solutions for latency constrained multi-hop, with particular interest in cellular inspired system models.  We aimed to develop new coding, signaling, and information theory techniques via a set of central new coding techniques in this area called transcoding. 

The research was integrated into educational offerings as well.  The project included an international component through collaboration with University College Dublin and Queen's University Belfast.

 

Intellectual Merit:

The project explored numerous topics in communications, signal processing, and information theory.  Major results of this project can be roughly categorized by the following three thrusts:

Thrust 1: A new design and analysis framework of multi-hop communications. This project developed a new transcoding framework, which exhibits superior delay-reliability tradeoff than the state-of-the art.  With the introduction of new micro-block-based signal processing techniques, the latency experienced in a multi-hop communication can be substantially shortened to a level comparable to that of the traditional single-hop communication.  The results pave the analytical foundation for running myriad low-latency-based applications over multi-hop communication networks.  

Thrust 2: Queueing delay minimization. This project developed and analyzed new physical-layer and network-layer solutions that minimize the queueing delay and improve the overall latency. By analyzing the queueing free coding architecture, one can simultaneously shorten the delay while improving the error protection. The proposed network-layer scheduling protocols uncover a new direct relationship between latency and the cyber-physical control system performance, and the project derived new solutions that can automatically adapt to varying underlying network traffic pattern and converge to the theoretical optimal performance. 

Thrust 3: Advanced waveform schemes and analysis. The project developed low-latency MIMO-based relay solution with new precoders for an in-band full-duplex relay, which balances the self-interference suppression and the transmission rate. With next-generation communication networks likely being implemented on untrusted hardware and potentially in the presence of interference, the project also developed new schemes for the relay nodes to quickly recognize and adapt to potential security concerns. MIMO channel estimation generally requires large overhead which reduces throughput and increases the latency through the network. This project has researched on various ways to reduce the MIMO channel estimation overhead, which helps to reduce the latency through the network.

 

Broader Impacts:

The digital divide between the urban and rural communities has continued to widen, and broadband access is one of the major reasons for this inequality. This project investigated existing and emerging multi-hop wireless technologies that could aid the development of rural and third world economies. One example application for transcoding is to provide cost effective coverage over smart agriculture fields that lack direct commercial wireless infrastructure, by providing multi-hop backhauling capability with low latency that is comparable to a typical single-hop communication. The results could also have direct impact on urban wireless communications that rely on dense, multihop connections and/or Internet-of-Things networks, for which it is prohibitively expensive to develop ubiquitous single-hop coverage for all the commercial and industry users. 

The research results of this project have been disseminated through technical research and survey papers in both the traditional communication and information theory societies and in other application-oriented communities like smart agriculture, precision farming, robotics, control, AI, nanotechnology, and during a talk through the IoT4Ag Engineering Research Center (ERC). The broad dissemination of knowledge broadened its reach.
